ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Combination of live virtual lectures and recorded lectures
Lectures are recorded for those who do not wish to attend the 8:45 AM lecture.
The lecture was live but you could also watch recordings. I went to live sessions.
Live virtual lectures were also recorded.
Live virtual lectures when possible, otherwise recorded lecture.
Expected in person lecture twice per week that was recorded for those who could not attend.
We had live lectures with recordings. The recordings were really helpful to view
just lecture
in person lectures, available to view recorded lectures after
Option to attend live virtual lectures on MW mornings, but most lectures were recorded and uploaded on to Canvas.
I went to some live lectures as well.
I attended some synchronous classes when I could.
You could attend class at the regular scheduled time period of you could watch it on your own time via a recorded lecture.
live virtual lecture
N/A
Excel homeworks
This course had recorded lectures.
virtual lecture

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Extremely applicable accounting skills and I greatly improved my familiarity with Excel.
I learned about financial statements, how the connect, how to make them when given a set of transactions, and how to analyze financial statements of public companies.

This is a great course to learn basic accounting. Professor Antle is great and really cares about his students. You should take this course if you want to learn introductory accounting skills or keep up with skills you gained over the summer at work/

Thorough overview of accounting. At the end of this course, you will be able to pick up the financial statements of any company and actually understand what is going on. This is an invaluable and necessary skill for anyone interested in working in something even just remotely related to business.
Improved my excel skills a lot while also getting a good grasp on how to follow and record the cash flows within companies.

I gained knowledge on how to read and build financial statements, how to log financial transactions as journal entries, enter them into T-accounts, and then balance all the transactions in the financial statements. I learned how to read financial statements and then extract the financial transactions that happened by reverse engineering the data on the statements.
I learned basic accounting, how to do journal entries, then record those in the t tabs, then fill out the income statement and cash flow statement (direct and indirect method)
I learned how to make or read ledgers, balance sheets, income statements, and cash flow statements. I also learned about discounting.
accounting skills
Developed the skills of accounting but also the knowledge of accounting principles and the functions of accounting within a larger entity.

Basic accounting skills, how to make an income statement/cash flow statement/etc., understanding how accountants look at the world and record different transactions, more comfortable with Excel as well as terms that are used to keep track of business operations and other finance decisions
I learned how to read financial statements. I also learned about interest. I also learned how to create cash flow statements. I developed a foundation for the basics of accounting.
A basic understanding of accounting. Nothing revolutionary, but certainly a good skill to have.
I've learned all about Microsoft excel and how to manipulate graphs, charts, etc.
i learned a lot more about how accounting works
Basics of accounting and valuation; financial statement analysis; dissecting real financial statements (10-Ks, etc.)
Tons of useful accounting knowledge such as balance sheets, income statements, cash flow statements
This was a great introductory course to accounting and business evaluation.
accounting and valuation

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It is very up to the student how much they put into the class and how much they want to learn. Extremely useful for the future and very applicable.
No weaknesses, this is one of the best and most useful classes I have taken at Yale. Prof. Antle teaches us SO much.
Excel work and also basic accounting skills that I learned over the summer at a job.

Strengths: you will learn a ton very quickly (especially if you don't know anything about accounting!). The material is straightforward: if you are willing to put in the work, you will get it. Doing the actual accounting is not difficult (it is fun for people who enjoy methodic work!), but the conceptual part can get tricky. 

Weaknesses: Not enough evaluations. Basically if you do the 2 problem sets and the first part of the final, you will get a B+. Those 2 problem sets and the first part of the final might take you 10 hours total. Yes, you read that right: 10 hours. If you are not content with a B+, your entire grade is determined by the two-hour Part 2 of the final exam. This means that you will have NO IDEA what your grade will be until basically grades come out at the end of the semester.

The semester was very i=uneven in my opinion with the first few weeks almost being too easy and then everything picking up and happening at the end. We often went very slowly over things that didn't matter as much and went quickly over things that might have been more important.

Strengths of the course was the constant reinforcement of excel techniques that were used in trying to understand the concepts. A possible way that it could be improved would be to make the introduction to some of the terms and concepts more clear before jumping into the modeling and excel work. Much of the excel work was very faced paced and there was an expected prior knowledge level that was unclear and if not met, made it very difficult to keep pace.

Strengths: Professor Antle is the most devoted professor who is always happy to answer questions or help students learn! Learning came through practice

Weaknesses: sometimes felt like we werent learning accounting the standard way

Strengths: Professor Antle is very nice and knowledgable in this field. The assignments are consistent and helpful with a lot of feedback provided through ExPrep and YALEiE. Weakness: This course needs better organization. Professor Antle needs to upload all assignments and files into one central location in a timely manner. At times it is hard finding where certain files are located.
Class is very early. We did not get a single grade back for this semester. I have no idea how I am doing.

Strengths engaging teacher (love Antle), good structure and organization (which means a lot during virtual times)

Weaknesses-- lectures were 1h15min where they could've been done in probably 30 min. Lots of wasted time in the lectures which was frustrating.

Prof. Antle does a great job reviewing the homeworks in class and the in-worksheet feedback makes the PSETS and final exam very approachable if you have been keeping up with the lectures. I wish there were some more written materials/guidance that students can refer to (no official textbook for this class) to think about and remember key terms, things to look out for, as well as where to go to answer specific questions we might have. Prof. Antle is very responsive over both email and Piazza so very grateful for his support throughout the semester.

The strengths of this course was the content. I think this was very important stuff to know when entering most professional fields. The weakness was the syllabus it was slightly confusing what actually counted for your grade and what was practice.
Professor Antle was great with the technology and made the material easy to understand over Zoom.

Strengths: the valuation aspect of the course was interesting and I wish we spent more time on it. Rick is very knowledgable on the subject matter.

Weaknesses: the class is very disorganized

The strengths of this course was the material. I found it very enjoyable to learn about accounting because I'm almost certain I will be using the skills I learned in this class after I graduate. The weaknesses of this course is that it had to be taught remotely. This is a class I believe would've been ran much more smoothly if it was in person.
I liked the assignments for practicing and I thought the self-contained excels were very cool. However, I thought the assignments were confusing sometimes with no direction.
Strengths: practice makes accounting, a lot of great application and practice problems from Professor Antle, dissecting real financial statements, very applicable and useful class; weaknesses: none

Phenomenal course. Loved the feedback on assignments, great way to check yourself before going down the wrong road. 
No improvements
Professor Antle's teaching style was amazing! He made accounting fun to learn.

strengths: Prof Antle worked very hard to make the classes interesting and utilize everything zoom had to offer. Everything was very well organized with the structure of the class.
weakness: It would be helpful to have a more clear explanation on how the modules and deadlines work at the beginning of the class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was very easy to transition this course online I believe because it is mostly a computer (Excel) course. Not really anything to improve on really.
Prof Antle did a great job

The course has a really great Canvas page. It is well organized, helps structure the learning process. It also offers a bunch of additional resources.

Professor Antle also makes great efforts to make the Zoom sessions dynamic and interesting. He has a green screen (yes, an actual green screen in his home), to make the videos look super professional. He even suited up for almost all of the lectures! He has 2 cameras, and will switch the angle of the recording to keep you awake. 

Engagement could perhaps be improved in lecture by asking students to keep their video on.
Giving a good time range to submit an assignment was a great help during COVID.

What succeeded the most was the shared screen function and powerpoint presentations that were used to discuss the concepts and demonstrate how to model all of the accounting techniques on excel. What could be improved is going at a slower pace in the excel modeling as it was sometimes very difficult to follow what was being done during lecture and do it yourself simultaneously.
Recorded lectures worked really well
class was fine
Allowing attendance to be counted on recorded lectures or live lectures. Allowed for a lot of flexibility which was important to me.

Prof. Antle did a great job making this class accessible to different student needs, especially during a pandemic. I was impressed by the different technology tools he used to make class engaging and effective. The homework assignments were graded on completion, the PSETS were posted with enough time to ask questions and review, and the final exam had a flexible time frame. I think there could be more regular office hours to ask questions outside of class time. I also appreciate how he made study groups at the beginning of the semester and look forward to hearing about how Prof. Antle builds community among students in different ways.
I think Professor Antle did a great job answering piazza and using zoom effectively. He did an awesome job for a pandemic semester.

Prof. Antle did an excellent job using Zoom to his advantage. I feel like it might have even helped, because Excel is so front and center in the course and we could easily follow along with every step.
I think that the professor did his best and did a fine job teaching and explaining the material over zoom.
I really appreciated how prof antle devoted himself to improving his lectures through obtaining streaming equipment. I think that this class was the best in terms of covid accomodations.

Succeeded: Recorded lectures, detailed practice problem sets and answer keys, going through problem sets live
Improvements: none off the top of my head
Being able to watch the lectures on your own schedule was fantastic.
This course was very friendly towards learning during the pandemic.
The lectures succeeded.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Most definitely. It was a very easy, useful course and can help you in almost any career in the future. Extremely minimal workload (approximately 1.5 hours a week) and I still learned so much. However, if you care a ton about your GPA, you might be quite nervous about this class, as there are really no grades until the final, but I believe everyone gets at least a B+ pretty much.
YES!! One of the most useful classes that is taught wonderfully and helpfully.
Yes, if you want to learn accounting or have an easy B+ credit, take it.

Yes, absolutely, if you are interested in working in anything related to business. By the end of the class, you will be able to pick up any company's financial statements and actually understand what is going on. That is an invaluable and necessary skill in the business world.

Also, the class is fast-paced and you will actually learn a ton in just one semester. It's a great investment of your time. It's honestly probably better than any accounting class you would take in business school. This will definitely give you a leg up in the real world. But warning: you will only get as much out of the class as you put in. There is barely any required work, so unless you put in efforts, you might actually not end up learning very much.

I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in how to build and read financial statements. There is very little that is discussed about valuation methods and the whole course is a comprehensive process of journaling financial transactions, logging them in t-accounts, and then transferring that information into the balancing of financial statements. Hence, someone who is interested in reading financial statements and understanding the process for how a transaction goes from initial transaction to financial statement data should take this course.
Yes i would recommend this class to anyone who wants to gain a foundation in accounting. Professor Antle makes learning fun

I really valued this course because it taught me the basics of valuations (discounted cash flows), accounting (journal entries, debits/credits, cash flows), and financial statement analysis. Professor Antle is great: the class progressed at just the right speed with just the right difficulty. He also had numerous fun and personal anecdotes to liven up the material -- it never once felt like a technical jargon overload.
Definitely if you have the space to do so. I learned basic accounting skills which are really useful to know in life.
if you are interested in learning accounting
Yes. Very useful life skills.

This was my first class in accounting, and at the beginning, I struggled to switch my mindset to think more like an accountant and was confused by the different vocabulary. However, as the semester progressed, I was able to familiarize myself with basic terminology and became more comfortable finding patterns and understanding how to fill out our assignments. I would recommend this to students who are interested in learning the basics of accounting in an accessible way. It was hard to stay on top of things with the pre-recorded lectures so I wouldn't recommend this to students who don't keep up with the lectures (I regret not doing this until too late). However, I learned a lot of practical skills and am grateful that I took this class. I took this class Credit/D and feel comfortable recommending this as a 5th class.
Yes, I would explain that I think its important to know the basics of accounting and this is a great introductory course to do that.
It's what you'd expect. If you are interested in accounting/believe it will be a useful skill, which I certainly do, then this is a great course to learn.
nah, unless the course is changed to focus more on valuation.
yes if you are interested in accounting!
Yes, very useful and applicable class.
Absolutely. It is a must take.
Yes! Accounting is so important if you're interested in a career in the financial industry, and Prof. Antle makes it so fun.
Yes, if you're interested in accounting!
